content.description: Climb any of the numerous lines on the Langlee Slab. Get creative (sit starts, traverses, etc.), because the climbing is not that hard.
content.protection: A single rack. There are some trees at the top for anchors, but bring long slings.
content.location: It is on the climber's right side of Langlee Slab.

content.description: Climb the vertical finger crack to the ledge.
content.protection: A standard rack. Use the vertical crack on the ledge to build a gear anchor. There are no trees for anchors.
content.location: It is on the climber's left of the Langlee Slab.

content.description: Climb the corner straight to the top. It is best to climb when it's low tide.
content.protection: A standard rack. There are trees at the top for an anchor.
content.location: From the climber's right edge of Langlee Slab, continue walking right around the corner, and you will see the obvious corner.

content.description: Climb the series of vertical finger cracks all the way to the top.
content.protection: A single rack. There is no gear anchor, so either hip belay your second up or go way back and use a tree.
content.location: This is in the center of Langlee Slab.

content.description: This is the main crag on Langlee Island. All the climbs here are 5.easy, so this is by no means a destination crag, but it is a unique place to check out if you ever have access to a boat and want to have some fun.
